doc.description: Enable the legacy 'Site visibility' privacy options.
doc.long_description:
By default the privacy options form displays a single checkbox to 'discourage' search engines from indexing the site. Hooking to this action serves a dual purpose: 1. Disable the single checkbox in favor of a multiple-choice list of radio buttons. 2. Open the door to adding additional radio button choices to the list.
 Hooking to this action also converts the 'Search engine visibility' heading to the more open-ended 'Site visibility' heading.
doc.long_description_html:
By default the privacy options form displays a single checkbox to 'discourage' search engines from indexing the site. Hooking to this action serves a dual purpose:

  1. Disable the single checkbox in favor of a multiple-choice list of radio buttons.
  2. Open the door to adding additional radio button choices to the list.

Hooking to this action also converts the 'Search engine visibility' heading to the more open-ended 'Site visibility' heading.

doc.description: Fires after WordPress has finished loading but before any headers are sent.
doc.long_description:
Most of WP is loaded at this stage, and the user is authenticated. WP continues to load on the {@see 'init'} hook that follows (e.g. widgets), and many plugins instantiate themselves on it for all sorts of reasons (e.g. they need a user, a taxonomy, etc.).
 If you wish to plug an action once WP is loaded, use the {@see 'wp_loaded'} hook below.
doc.long_description_html:
Most of WP is loaded at this stage, and the user is authenticated. WP continues to load on the {@see 'init'} hook that follows (e.g. widgets), and many plugins instantiate themselves on it for all sorts of reasons (e.g. they need a user, a taxonomy, etc.).

If you wish to plug an action once WP is loaded, use the {@see 'wp_loaded'} hook below.

doc.description: Fires early when editing the widgets displayed in sidebars.
Fires before a particular screen is loaded.
doc.long_description:
The load-* hook fires in a number of contexts. This hook is for plugin screens where a callback is provided when the screen is registered.
 The dynamic portion of the hook name, `$page_hook`, refers to a mixture of plugin page information including: 1. The page type. If the plugin page is registered as a submenu page, such as for    Settings, the page type would be 'settings'. Otherwise the type is 'toplevel'. 2. A separator of '_page_'. 3. The plugin basename minus the file extension.
 Together, the three parts form the `$page_hook`. Citing the example above, the hook name used would be 'load-settings_page_pluginbasename'.
doc.long_description_html:
The load-* hook fires in a number of contexts. This hook is for plugin screens where a callback is provided when the screen is registered.

The dynamic portion of the hook name, $page_hook, refers to a mixture of plugin page information including:

  1. The page type. If the plugin page is registered as a submenu page, such as for Settings, the page type would be 'settings'. Otherwise the type is 'toplevel'.
  2. A separator of 'page'.
  3. The plugin basename minus the file extension.

Together, the three parts form the $page_hook. Citing the example above, the hook name used would be 'load-settings_page_pluginbasename'.

doc.description: Fires before a particular screen is loaded.

The load-* hook fires in a number of contexts. This hook is for core screens.
 The dynamic portion of the hook name, `$pagenow`, is a global variable referring to the filename of the current page, such as 'admin.php', 'post-new.php' etc. A complete hook for the latter would be 'load-post-new.php'.
doc.long_description_html:
The load-* hook fires in a number of contexts. This hook is for core screens.

The dynamic portion of the hook name, $pagenow, is a global variable referring to the filename of the current page, such as 'admin.php', 'post-new.php' etc. A complete hook for the latter would be 'load-post-new.php'.

doc.description: Fires when _publish_post_hook() is called during an XML-RPC request.
Add additional APIs to the Really Simple Discovery (RSD) endpoint.
Fires scheduled events.

tags.name: param
tags.content: Name of the hook that was scheduled to be fired.

tags.name: param
tags.content: The arguments to be passed to the hook.

doc.description: Fires when a post is transitioned from one status to another.
doc.long_description:
The dynamic portions of the hook name, `$new_status` and `$post->post_type`, refer to the new post status and post type, respectively.
 Please note: When this action is hooked using a particular post status (like 'publish', as `publish_{$post->post_type}`), it will fire both when a post is first transitioned to that status from something else, as well as upon subsequent post updates (old and new status are both the same).
 Therefore, if you are looking to only fire a callback when a post is first transitioned to a status, use the {@see 'transition_post_status'} hook instead.
doc.long_description_html:
The dynamic portions of the hook name, $new_status and $post->post_type, refer to the new post status and post type, respectively.

Please note: When this action is hooked using a particular post status (like 'publish', as publish_{$post->post_type}), it will fire both when a post is first transitioned to that status from something else, as well as upon subsequent post updates (old and new status are both the same).

Therefore, if you are looking to only fire a callback when a post is first transitioned to a status, use the {@see 'transition_post_status'} hook instead.

doc.description: Fires when a post is transitioned from one status to another.
doc.long_description: The dynamic portions of the hook name, `$new_status` and `$old_status`, refer to the old and new post statuses, respectively.
doc.long_description_html: The dynamic portions of the hook name, $new_status and $old_status, refer to the old and new post statuses, respectively.

doc.description: Used to call the registered callback for a plugin screen.
doc.long_description:
This hook uses a dynamic hook name, `$page_hook`, which refers to a mixture of plugin page information including: 1. The page type. If the plugin page is registered as a submenu page, such as for    Settings, the page type would be 'settings'. Otherwise the type is 'toplevel'. 2. A separator of '_page_'. 3. The plugin basename minus the file extension.
 Together, the three parts form the `$page_hook`. Citing the example above, the hook name used would be 'settings_page_pluginbasename'.
doc.long_description_html:
This hook uses a dynamic hook name, $page_hook, which refers to a mixture of plugin page information including:

  1. The page type. If the plugin page is registered as a submenu page, such as for Settings, the page type would be 'settings'. Otherwise the type is 'toplevel'.
  2. A separator of 'page'.
  3. The plugin basename minus the file extension.

Together, the three parts form the $page_hook. Citing the example above, the hook name used would be 'settings_page_pluginbasename'.
